case_vignette: An otherwise healthy 60-year-old dishwasher presents with asymptomatic green discoloration of his right middle fingernail over a period of 2 months. The discoloration began from the distal margin. He denies wearing gloves while working and reports a tendency to pick at his nails when nervous. On examination, distal onycholysis and green discoloration are present exclusively on the right middle nail plate starting from the distal edge without signs of paronychia. Dermoscopy reveals pigment localization under the nail plate.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
The nail on my right middle finger has turned green over the last 2 months.
Have you experienced any trauma or injury to the nail or finger?
No, I haven't experienced any trauma or injury to it.
Do you have any other symptoms, such as pain, swelling, or discharge from the affected nail area?
No, there's no pain, swelling, or discharge from the nail.
Do you have a history of frequent water exposure or work in a damp environment?
Yes, I work as a dishwasher, so my hands are often in water.
Do you have any previous history of nail or skin infections?
No, I don't have any history of nail or skin infections.
Has the color change spread to any other nails or just the one finger?
Just the one finger.
Are there any changes in shape or texture of the affected nail?
Yes, the nail has lifted up a bit at the end.
Do you have any history of diabetes or a compromised immune system?
No, I'm otherwise healthy.
Has anyone in your family had similar nail issues or a history of fungal infections?
No, nobody in my family has had similar nail issues or a history of fungal infections.
Final Diagnosis: Green nail syndrome (Chloronychia) due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection.
